author: Tanu Kulkarni
text:
The faculty and students of the National Institute of Design, Bengaluru, are working on giving stations and coaches a facelift.

Many of India’s railway stations and trains are set to get a splash of colour and new designs that will draw inspiration from our wildlife.

The faculty and students of the National Institute of Design (NID) Bengaluru, along with their counterparts from Ahmedabad and Gandhinagar, are working with Indian Railways to give stations and coaches a facelift.

The faculty of the Bengaluru campus have submitted eight colour palettes for a high speed train that is to be launched in the 2016-17 financial year. Two have been shortlisted, said Nijoo Dubey, associate faculty, who is heading this project along with three students. One of the colour schemes — with orange, dark blue and grey — has been inspired by the cheetah while another with bright green and two shades of blue draws from the beauty of the peacock.

Ms. Dubey said the designs are for the exterior and the interior of the train. “Our designs are centred on the themes of pride, high speed and precision,” she said.

The students and faculty of NID in the three campuses have also come up with several ideas to jazz up the coaches, interior utilities, passenger comfort, branding and railway station utilities. A railway design centre was set up in the three campuses after the institute entered into a Memorandum of Understanding with Indian Railways last April for this purpose.
title: NID splashes colour on Indian Railways
